#Text=Thomas Charnock
#Text=For the English politician , see Thomas Charnock ( MP ) .
#Text=Thomas Charnock ( 1516/1524/1526 – 1581 ) was an English alchemist and occultist who devoted his life to the quest for the Philosopher 's Stone .
#Text=Life
#Text=A native of the Isle of Thanet , Charnock spent most of his life in Combwich , a small village on the Steart Peninsula , near Bridgwater in the west of England .
#Text=His unpublished notebooks are useful , not just for an understanding of Elizabethan attitudes towards alchemy in general , but for the insight they give to Charnock 's life and thoughts .

#Text=Apart from the usual preoccupations of his profession , he also had an amateur interest in Atlantic exploration , and in his study he had an astrolabe , maps , a globe and other navigational instruments .

#Text=He rather quaintly described the difficulties he found in trying to decipher Medieval English texts on alchemy , which were " as harde to my understanding as yff I had harde one rede a booke off the language off the natione which dwell in the fourth parte off the worlde named America . "

column1: #Text=His uncle , also called Thomas Charnock , had been an alchemist , as well as the confessor to Henry VII .
#Text=Thomas ' interest in the subject appears to have been stimulated when he inherited his uncle 's books while in his teens .
#Text=Although he married in 1562 , and had two children , he preferred the life of scholarly solitude , made clear in the preamble of the treatise he wrote for Elizabeth I .

#Text=He says that his pursuit of the Philosopher 's Stone has in large measure been impeded by " worldly necessities " , and that the said Stone is reserved for men who have the gift of " solitariness . "
#Text=Charnock took this seriously enough to vainly ask Elizabeth to allow him to carry on his experiments in the Tower of London , or another " solitary place . "
#Text=This was probably stimulated by the hostility of his neighbours , which forced him to barricade himself in his cottage .

#Text=It seems obvious from the hostility he engendered locally that his neighbours had deep superstitious fears , which Charnock did much to encourage , describing himself as a magus as well as a philosopher , who had mastery of " dark and misty terms . "

#Text=After his death , it was reported that no-one would live in his former cottage , which was " troublesome and haunted by spirits and that its owner had a reputation as a troublesome person and a conjurer . "
#Text=His work was tiresome and demanding , requiring him , amongst other things , to keep a fire burning at a constant temperature .
#Text=Quite often he would wake up in the night , troubled that things were not going well .
#Text=Concerns over servants , fires , and the cost of fuel were steady preoccupations .
#Text=He was also pursued by fairly constant bad luck : " God send me better fortune or else I am clean discouraged and will turn from philosophy to husbandry and go and get me unto the plough . "
#Text=When England went to war with France in 1557 , the local Justice of the Peace , who seems to have been a personal enemy , made sure that Thomas was forced into military service .
#Text=In frustration , he took a hatchet to his equipment , smashing glasses and pots alike .
#Text=Undaunted , Charnock was back at his experiments seven years later .

#Text=Charnock himself was always aware of the ambiguity of his art , warning that Roger Bacon , the founder of English alchemy , had come dangerously close to the occult , and had ultimately been unsuccessful in his quest for the Stone because the Devil was his familiar .
#Text=His own search for the Stone proceeded in the face of one failure after another .
#Text=Even so , he kept his fires burning for three years constantly , which " brought him more joy than any worldly goods . "
#Text=He died in April 1581 .
#Text=Charnock was buried in Otterhampton Church , near Bridgwater . [ 1 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=Charnock married , in 1562 , Agnes Norden , and settled at Stockland-Bristol in Somersetshire . [ 1 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=The following works attributed to Charnock were printed in Elias Ashmole 's Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum
#Text=Breviary of Philosophy . 1557 .
#Text=An autobiographical account of Charnock 's alchemistic experiences [ 2 ]
#Text=Aenigma ad Alchimiam . 1572 .
#Text=Aenigma de Alchimiae . 1572 .
#Text=Fragments coppied From Thomas Charnock 's owne hand writing . 1574.
